greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: number of k-ary n-tuples (a_1,..,a_n) such that the string a_1...a_n is preprime.
comment: A string is prime if it is nonempty and lexicographically less than all of its proper suffixes. A string is preprime if it is a nonempty prefix of a prime, on some alphabet. See the Knuth reference, section 7.2.1.1.
reference: D. E. Knuth. Generating All Tuples and Permutations. The Art of Computer Programming, Vol. 4, Fascicle 2, Addison-Wesley, 2005.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 1..141, flattened
example: T(4, 3) counts the 32 ternary preprimes of length 4 which are:
Triangle starts (compare the table A143328 as a square array):
maple: f0 := proc(n) option remember; unapply(k^n-add(f0(d)(k),d=divisors(n) minus{n}),k) end;
f2 := proc(n) option remember; unapply(f0(n)(x)/n,x) end;
g2 := proc(n) option remember; unapply(add(f2(j)(x),j=1..n),x) end;
mathematica: t[n_, k_] := Sum[(1/j)*MoebiusMu[j/d]*k^d, {j, 1, n}, {d, Divisors[j]}]; Table[t[n, k], {n, 1, 10}, {k, 1, n}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jul 26 2013 *)
program: # This algorithm generates and counts all k-ary n-tuples
# (a_1,..,a_n) such that the string a_1...a_n is preprime.
# It is algorithm F in Knuth 7.2.1.1.
return add((1/j)*add(moebius(j/d)*k^d for d in divisors(j))  for j in (1..n))
for n in (1..9): print([A215474(n,k) for k in (1..n)])
results.author: _Peter Luschny_, Aug 12 2012
